text: Startup India Initiative: The Government of India launched Startup India in 2016 to build a strong ecosystem for nurturing innovation and startups in the country. Key benefits include self-certification for labor and environment laws, tax exemption for 3 consecutive years under Section 80-IAC, and fast-track patent examination. Startups can get up to 80% rebate on patent filing fees. The initiative also includes Startup India Seed Fund Scheme providing up to Rs. 50 lakhs for proof of concept, prototype development, and product trials.
title: Startup India Initiative Overview

text: Fund of Funds for Startups (FFS): SIDBI manages the Fund of Funds with a corpus of Rs. 10,000 crores to provide funding support to startups through Alternative Investment Funds (AIFs). The scheme does not directly invest in startups but provides capital to SEBI-registered AIFs who in turn invest in startups. This creates a multiplier effect, enabling more capital flow into the startup ecosystem. Over 90 AIFs have been registered under this scheme.
title: Fund of Funds for Startups

text: Credit Guarantee Scheme for Startups (CGSS): This scheme provides credit guarantees to banks and financial institutions for loans to DPIIT-recognized startups. The maximum guarantee cover is Rs. 10 crores with a guarantee period up to the tenure of the loan. This helps startups access debt funding without requiring collateral, making it easier for early-stage companies to secure working capital.
title: Credit Guarantee Scheme for Startups

text: Digital India Programme: A flagship programme to transform India into a digitally empowered society and knowledge economy. Key initiatives include BharatNet for rural broadband, Digital Locker for document storage, and various e-governance services. The programme creates opportunities for startups in areas like digital payments, e-governance solutions, cybersecurity, and digital health.
title: Digital India Programme

text: RBI Regulatory Sandbox for Fintech: The Reserve Bank of India has established a regulatory sandbox framework to enable live testing of innovative fintech products and services. Startups can test their solutions in a controlled environment before full-scale deployment. Focus areas include retail payments, cross-border payments, MSME lending, and digital KYC. Maximum validity is 6 months, extendable by another 6 months.
title: RBI Fintech Regulatory Sandbox

text: SEBI Framework for Fintech: SEBI has introduced various regulations for fintech companies operating in capital markets. This includes guidelines for robo-advisory services, algorithm trading, and crowdfunding platforms. Startups offering investment advisory services need to register as Investment Advisers. Those offering portfolio management require a minimum net worth of Rs. 50 lakhs.
title: SEBI Fintech Regulations

text: US Small Business Administration Programs: The SBA offers several programs for startups including 7(a) loans (up to $5 million), 504 loans for fixed assets, and microloans up to $50,000. The Small Business Investment Company (SBIC) program licenses private investment funds to provide equity and debt financing to small businesses. The SBIR/STTR programs provide over $3 billion annually in grants for R&D.
title: US Small Business Programs

text: UK Enterprise Investment Scheme (EIS): EIS offers tax reliefs to individual investors who buy shares in high-risk companies. Investors can get up to 30% income tax relief on investments up to £1 million. Companies can raise up to £5 million per year through EIS. The Seed Enterprise Investment Scheme (SEIS) offers 50% tax relief for investments in very early-stage companies, up to £100,000 per tax year.
title: UK Enterprise Investment Scheme
